repnme.cdata!:
Benin - Public Expenditure Reform
            Adjustment Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows : the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modes,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that budget
            reform is a long-term process that will take decades to
            succeed in most member countries. The main issue, at the
            design stage, is to select a few strategic kick-off
            activities and operational targets that can be
            completed/achieved in one or two years. The success of a
            long-term budget reform will obviously depend on the
            long-term commitment of both the government and its
            financiers. A multi-sector budget reform program needs to
            mobilize considerable support from the Bank and possibly
            other donors, particularly at the supervision stage.
            Introducing entirely new budget preparation and evaluation
            techniques may require a significant input of technical
            assistance to be financed by donors. Both the Budget
            Directorate and most of the other departments in the
            Ministry of Finance and Economy tend to give priority to
            what they see as their main operational and administrative
            functions and do not have the staff, the time and the
            capacity to guide other ministries in the design, execution
            and monitoring of program-budgets. For the short-term
            future, the Bank may also wish to consider the following
            recommendations: the next phase of Bank programs in support
            of budget reforms should first aim at consolidating initial
            results; the fact that new ministries want to join the
            program-budget process shows the vitality of the reform but
            also creates a major absorptive capacity constraint.

repnme.cdata!:
Benin - Public Expenditure Reform Adustment
            Credit Project - SUPPLEMENTAL CREDIT

abstracts.cdata!:
This supplemental credit for the Public
            Expenditure Reform Adjustment Credit (PERAC) Project, will
            assist in meeting Benin's increased financing
            requirements, caused by an unanticipated decline in the
            international price of cotton. The absence of this
            supplemental financing would jeopardize the
            Government's ability to keep macroeconomic, and public
            expenditure reform program on track, jeopardizing as well
            the delivery of basic social services. Despite slower
            progress on the structural reform agenda, significant
            progress was registered in critical areas of the cotton
            sector, and budget management reform. The supplemental
            financing would enhance the impact of the PERAC project,
            contributing not only to maintaining the increase in
            allocations to education and health services, but in
            protecting cotton producers' incomes, allowing poverty
            alleviation efforts, through the provision of a subsidy to
            all cotton farmers.

repnme.cdata!:
Benin - Public Expenditure Reform
            Adjustment Credit (PERAC) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Expenditure Reform Adjustment
            Credit (PERAC) aims to a) increase the impact of government
            expenditures on economic and social development and poverty
            reduction; b) improve governance by providing a transparent
            system of budgeting linking budget allocations to program
            objectives and sector strategies; c) strengthen the
            government's administrative capacity to manage public
            expenditures efficiently; and d) establish a fiduciary
            framework enabling the provision of external financial
            assistance. The credit is based on a set of institutional
            reforms and capacity building essential to reach these
            objectives. These include reform of the budget preparation
            system through the use of performance budgeting;
            strengthening of the administrative/institutional capacity
            for more efficient and timely budget execution and
            reporting; establishment of a fiduciary framework; and
            greater use of monitoring and evaluation techniques for
            public expenditures.
